inputs.task: Design and improve the LaunchBase homepage from first principles
inputs.whitePaper:
LaunchBase is an operating system for small businesses.
Not a website builder. Not another tool. Not a one-time agency project.

LaunchBase is ongoing ownership of a business's digital operating layer:
- website uptime + maintenance
- lead capture + forms
- monitoring + safety decisions
- updates + publishing cadence
- integrations + visibility
- logging + accountability

LaunchBase exists because most small businesses already have tools, but no one owns the system.
They have a website, a payment tool, a calendar, a Google profile, and logins…
…but the owner still carries the burden of making sure everything works.

LaunchBase sells relief from that cognitive load.

Core customer pain: The customer isn't buying a website. They're buying the ability to stop thinking about:
- "Is it still working?"
- "Did that form actually send?"
- "What should I post?"
- "Is anything broken?"
- "Am I missing something?"

This is background anxiety, not a feature gap.
The enemy is not "lack of tools."
The enemy is lack of ownership.

LaunchBase replaces the customer as the default system-checker.

Promise:
✅ Change is reversible
✅ Non-action is safe
✅ Silence is a valid decision
✅ Every action is logged
✅ Customer sees their real site before paying
✅ LaunchBase acts only after approval

The brand is accountability.
LaunchBase is responsibility-as-a-service.

Target customer:
- owner-operator
- service business
- small team
- not "tech obsessed"
- wants a business to run, not to "manage tools"

Tone: calm, competent, honest, operationally serious, safety-first, premium but not flashy.
This is a systems product, not a "creative brand party."

Design objective:
✅ Create instant trust
✅ Communicate the contract clearly
✅ Show the "safe-by-default" nature
✅ Make "Hand It Off" feel low-risk
✅ Explain observability in plain English
✅ Look premium enough to justify recurring ownership

currentCopy.hero: Stop carrying the system in your head. Hand it off. Keep visibility.
currentCopy.problem: No one owns the system. You're the fallback for everything.
currentCopy.solution: LaunchBase becomes the owner. You stay informed, not involved.
currentCopy.trust: Safe by default. Fully logged. Reversible.

inputs.audience: Owner-operators of service businesses (fitness studios, coffee shops, consulting firms) who want stability and accountability, not tool management
inputs.tone: Calm, minimal, trustworthy, premium. Avoid hype. Avoid 'AI magic.' Avoid exaggerated claims.
inputs.constraints: Mobile-first. Must feel like 'responsibility-as-a-service.' Must emphasize safety, reversibility, observability. Must reduce mental load while reading.

proposedChanges.value: Ensure the hero section is the first visible element, with a clear and minimal design. Include a subtle background pattern or image that conveys 'systems' to reinforce the message of responsibility and ownership.
proposedChanges.rationale: A visually appealing hero section will capture attention immediately, reinforcing the core message of handing off responsibility.
risks: Might distract from the core message if too visually complex.

proposedChanges.value: Combine the 'Problem' and 'Solution' sections into a single two-column layout with a visual divider, allowing users to see the problem and its resolution side by side.
proposedChanges.rationale: This layout reduces cognitive load by immediately presenting the problem and its solution in a clear, concise manner.
risks: May require careful visual balance to avoid clutter.

proposedChanges.value: Add a sticky primary CTA button for 'Learn More' that appears after a 40% scroll to guide users towards deeper engagement with the content.
proposedChanges.rationale: A sticky CTA ensures potential customers always have an option to explore further, increasing conversion opportunities.
risks: Persistent elements may distract if not implemented subtly.

proposedChanges.value: Convert pricing tables into card formats with one highlighted tier that is recommended, and include key 'what you get' bullets for clarity.
proposedChanges.rationale: Card formats are more visually digestible and highlight key features, improving understanding and aiding decision-making.

proposedChanges.value: Integrate a timeline or infographic that visually represents the 'safe-by-default' promise, showing reversibility and logging in action.
proposedChanges.rationale: Visual representation of trust elements can make complex assurances more tangible and believable.
risks: Could become too complex if not clearly executed.

proposedChanges.value: Move the Observability section directly after the Hero section and compress it to three concise bullet points with an optional expandable 'Learn More' link.
proposedChanges.rationale: Placing observability early emphasizes transparency and control, aligning with user concerns.
risks: Might reduce the perceived depth of information.

proposedChanges.value: Add a subtle animated scroll hint at the bottom of the hero section to encourage users to explore further.
proposedChanges.rationale: Visual cues can guide users smoothly through the page, improving engagement with the content.
risks: Animations may distract if too prominent.

proposedChanges.value: Use 48px H1 (mobile: 32px) with line-height 1.1 for hero headline to create calm, confident tone
proposedChanges.rationale: A larger headline with ample line-height reinforces a feeling of calm and confidence, essential for a service that promises to alleviate cognitive load.
risks: May require adjustments for smaller screens

proposedChanges.rationale: Generous spacing between sections helps to maintain a clean and premium aesthetic that reduces mental overload while reading.
risks: Could lead to increased scrolling on mobile devices

proposedChanges.value: Use pill-shaped buttons with 16px padding, subtle shadow, no gradients
proposedChanges.rationale: Pill-shaped buttons with subtle shadows provide a more premium and approachable feel, aligning with the brand's operational seriousness and calm tone.
risks: Subtle shadow may not be noticeable on all displays

proposedChanges.value: Set max text width to 65ch for body copy to improve readability
proposedChanges.rationale: Setting a maximum text width ensures readability and comfort, reducing cognitive load and supporting the brand's calm and competent tone.
risks: May require reflowing content for longer texts

proposedChanges.value: Add 3-chip row below hero: 'Safe by default • Fully auditable • Reversible changes'
proposedChanges.rationale: Chips visually reinforce key trust elements, making the promise of safety and accountability immediately clear.
risks: Chips may not be instantly clear to all users

proposedChanges.value: Use card style with soft borders and subtle drop shadow for section highlights
proposedChanges.rationale: A card style with soft borders and subtle shadows provides a visual hierarchy that remains calm and organized, emphasizing important information without overwhelming the user.
risks: Inconsistent card styles could lead to visual clutter

proposedChanges.value: Ensure all text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 against background
proposedChanges.rationale: Meeting contrast standards ensures readability for all users, reinforcing the brand's commitment to accessibility and inclusivity.
risks: May limit color choices for other design elements

proposedChanges.value: Include audit log preview pattern with timestamp and action summary
proposedChanges.rationale: An audit log preview with timestamps and summaries enhances transparency, building trust by showing the 'fully logged' nature of the service.
risks: May require backend integration for real-time updates

assumptions: Design implementation will maintain the calm, trustworthy tone specified in the white paper

swarm.reason: Missing craft or critic artifact for collapse
